awd_titl_txt: Student Design Essay Competition "Challenges in the Design of Complex Systems"; Travel Support to ASME IDETC 2018, ASME IDETC 2019, and ASME IDETC 2020 Conferences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the NSF goal to 'achieve excellence in U.S. Science, mathematics, engineering, and technology education at all levels', and will 'provide opportunities for young people that will attract them to and prepare them for careers in science, mathematics, and engineering'. Through a student essay competition, undergraduate and graduate students will be selected to attend a premier conference in engineering and systems design. The essay assignment challenges students to consider the effect of global competitiveness on engineering design practices, particularly in light of complex systems, and articulate their vision for the future of engineering and systems design. This exercise promotes the type of thinking skills necessary for innovators and researchers in engineering. The conference experience promotes growth in individual students and can also serve to strengthen the overall research quality of the research at the student's home institution when this knowledge is shared among their peers. 

The objective of this award is to promote undergraduate and graduate student professional development in engineering and systems design through an essay competition and support for travel to a research conference. A secondary objective is to encourage students to think deeply about what engineering design of complex systems will be like 20-30 years in the future. The competition will be publicized broadly, with students from a variety of engineering disciplines encouraged to compete. They will communicate their thoughts on the competition topic in an essay which will be judged by a distinguished group of engineering design researchers and educators. Travel funds will be provided for students who are selected through the design essay competition. A poster session will be organized at the conference to give the students an opportunity to interact with researchers and discuss their ideas on the future of engineering design of complex systems. Winning essays will be featured on a website so that they are accessible to a broad audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Student Design Essay Competition "Challenges in the Design of Complex Systems”

AWARD 1835957 (2018-2024)

This award provides the funds for academically talented students to attend the annual American Society of Mechanical Engineers' (ASME's) premier engineering design conference, The International Design Engineering Technical Conferences. IDETC.  Students submit essays on the future of engineering design. The essays are judged by a panel of faculty from across the United States using review criteria similar to those the NSF uses for the review of proposals.  Undergraduates and graduate students compete in separate categories. Winning students are awarded $1,500 for travel to IDETC and they are invited to present their work in the form of posters. They also receive certificates at the Design Engineering Division Awards luncheon. They also attend sessions and meet leaders in the field. All of the funds received under this award are used to support student travel and participation in the conference. .At the IDETC, ASME provides poster space and certificates for the winners.  During the COVID pandemic, the conference was held virtually, but the students were able to attend the entire conference virtually and they received certificates. Over the years that this award was in force, 38 awards were given. 9 awards went to undergraduates. 10 awards were given teams and the prize was divided among them.

It is imperative to encourage some of our best and brightest students to become part of the engineering design research community.  The competition application consists of an essay on the future of engineering design and manufacturing, a future is which the current students will lead the engineering design research community.  Writing these essays encourages critical thinking opportunities and fosters opportunities for thoughtful students regardless their university, advisor, gender, ethnic background or disability status. When at the conference students can discuss their work, evaluate how their work compares with the current state of research in our field, network, and apply for positions.

Although the period of this award covers 2018-2023, this competition has been in place since 1998. Our goals are:

(1) Encourage students to start and continue graduate studies

(2)  Encourage students to participate in the technical dialog about engineering design and provide opportunities for the students to present their work and discuss it in an international forum of experts. In addition to the feedback the reviewers provide on the essays, students present their work in the form of posters. Several of our winners have gone on to win Best Paper Awards in various sub-conferences at the IDETC. In 2006, one of our essay award winners, Jiten Patel, also took the opportunity to participate in the student mechanisms competition where, as an undergraduate student, he took first place overall – both the undergraduate division and the graduate division. He then went on to complete a PhD.

(3)   Encourage students to become faculty members. Over the years, 27 of those who have won the award have gone on to become faculty members and many of them send encourage their own students to submit to the conference. Those that we know about include:

  1. Arunava Banerjee, University of Alberta 
  2. Hannah Budinoff, University of Arizona 
  3. Benjamin Caldwell, La Tourneau University 
  4. Abigail Clark, University of Minnesota, Duluth 
  5. Mahmoud Dinar, University of North Carolina, Charlotte 
  6. Mohammad Fazelpour, University of Maryland, College Park 
  7. Scott Ferguson, North Carolina State University 
  8. Lin Guo, South Dakota School of Mones and Technology 
  9. Elizabeth Kames, Florida Polytechnic University 
  10. Xiaoyang Mao, Nanjing University of Science and Technology 
  11. Zhenjun Ming, Beijing Institute of Technology 
  12. Greg Mocko, Clemson University 
  13. Beshoy Morkos, University of Georgia 
  14. Philip Odonkor, Stevens Institute of Technology 
  15. Andrew Olewnik, University at Buffalo 
  16. Jitesh Panchal, Washington State University, currently Purdue University 
  17. Rahul Renu, Francis Marion University 
  18. Samira Sadeghi, University of Alberta 
  19. Chiradeep Sen, Clemson University 
  20. Joshua Summers, Clemson University, currently at University of Texas, Dallas 
  21. Khadija Tahera, Open University, UK 
  22. Cassandra Telenko, Georgia Institute of Technology
  23. Noe Vargas-Hernandez, University of Texas El Paso, currently at University of Texas, Rio Grande Valley 
  24. Ru Wang, Beijing Institute of Technology 
  25. Wenshan Wang, Carnegie Mellon University 
  26. Christopher Williams, Virginia Tech 
  27. Dazhong Wu, University of Central Florida 

We are grateful for the help of the faculty who reviewed the essays – and acknowledge them in alphabetical order:

  1. Mathew Bohm, Florida Polytechnic University
